content:
Syphilis: Causes, signs and prevention

Syphilis is a common, rapidly transmitted sexually transmitted disease that causes many serious complications. Currently, there is no vaccine for the disease, so prevention is better than cure.

What is syphilis?
Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by a bacteria called Treponema pallidum. According to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the rate of syphilis in women shows signs of decreasing, but in men, especially men who have sex with men, is increasing.
Similar to other sexually transmitted diseases, syphilis is difficult to diagnose because infected people often do not have any symptoms for many years. If syphilis infection lasts too long and is not treated properly, the disease can cause major damage to important internal organs such as the heart, brain... (1)
Some images about syphilis

Signs of the disease in each stage
Timing is very important for disease treatment. The same goes for syphilis. Recognizing the stage not only helps the patient have more chances of being cured but also avoids the risk of spreading it to relatives and partners.
According to Dr. Doan Ngoc Thien, Department of Andrology, Tam Anh General Hospital System, syphilis if not diagnosed and treated can persist for many years and is currently divided into 2 stages: early syphilis and late syphilis. (2)
1. Early syphilis
Stage I syphilis: The patient still lives normally and does not have any symptoms. However, the disease is most contagious during this and subsequent stages. Usually, the main stage of syphilis begins about 3-4 weeks (about 9 - 90 days) after bacterial infection. The patient develops a small, round ulcer called a chancre. Chancre is not painful but is highly infectious. These sores can appear anywhere bacteria entered the body such as the mouth, genitals or anus (or can be in non-genital locations). The wound will heal on its own in about 3-10 weeks whether treated or not. The patient may not notice the appearance of a chancre or find that the chancre disappears on its own. If not diagnosed and treated during this period, after 4-8 weeks from the appearance of the initial lesion, the disease will progress to stage II syphilis; Stage II syphilis: High risk of infection to others. Syphilis during this period is often easily confused with another disease such as drug allergy or psoriasis. With signs such as skin rash and sore throat. These rashes do not itch and usually appear on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet, but can also occur anywhere on the body. Some people don't even notice the rash before it disappears. Other symptoms of stage 2 syphilis may also include: headache, swollen lymph nodes, fatigue, fever, weight loss, hair loss, joint pain... There may be neurological signs: one-sided deafness , ophthalmic nerve paralysis, uveitis, meningitis. Symptoms of stage II syphilis can go away on their own even without any treatment. However, if the patient is not treated, the disease will progress to latent syphilis.; Latent syphilis: no clinical signs or symptoms. Therefore, it can only be detected by serum testing. Divided into 2 types: Divided into two stages: early latent (less than two years) and late latent (more than two years). Without treatment, all patients will be asymptomatic 12 â€“ 24 months after initial infection.
2. Late syphilis
Stage III syphilis: Appears often months or years after chancre appears in one-third of cases if not treated. Complications include: deep lesions, gums in the skin, bones, internal organs, cardiovascular and nervous system. At this stage, the patient is less likely to infect their partner because the spirochetes have penetrated and localized in the internal organs, no longer in the skin or mucous membranes.

Cause of syphilis
Doctors from the Department of Andrology, Tam Anh General Hospital System said that the cause of syphilis is a bacteria called Treponema pallidum. This type of bacteria was discovered in 1905, shaped like a spring with 6-14 spirals. Treponema pallidum's resistance is very weak, it cannot live more than a few hours outside the human body. The appropriate temperature for spirochetes to grow is 37*C. Soap and antiseptics can kill spirochetes in a few minutes.
The disease is spread when a healthy person comes into direct contact with an infected person's syphilis chancre through vaginal, anal or oral sex. The disease can also be transmitted indirectly through contaminated objects or objects or through scratches on the skin or mucous membranes. In addition, the disease can be transmitted through blood or from mother to child during pregnancy.
Once cured, syphilis will not recur. However, you can get reinfected if you come into contact with another person's syphilis sores.

Who is at risk of getting the disease?
Anyone who is sexually active can get syphilis. However, the disease easily appears in high-risk groups such as:
Having sex without using protection measures; Having sex with multiple partners; Gay sex; HIV infection, the virus that causes AIDS

How long is the incubation period for syphilis?
The incubation period of syphilis is on average 3-4 weeks (9-90 days). This is an important stage to detect and completely cure the disease. At this time, syphilitic chancre begins to appear through round spots, less than 2cm in size, painless, and without raised edges.
Serious lesions of syphilis will appear between 1-15 years later and cause many serious complications for the patient.

Dangerous complications of syphilis
If not treated promptly and properly, syphilis not only leads to damage throughout the patient's body but also causes many other dangerous complications such as:
1. Small bumps or tumors
Known as sebaceous cysts, these bumps can develop on the skin, bones, liver or any other organ in a person with late-stage syphilis.
2. Neurological problems
Syphilis can cause a number of problems with the nervous system such as: headaches, meningitis, hearing loss, decreased vision and possibly blindness, dementia, loss of pain and temperature sensation, Sexual dysfunction in men, bladder incontinence, cardiovascular problems...
3. HIV infection
People with sexually transmitted syphilis or other genital ulcers are estimated to have a 2-5 times increased risk of HIV infection. Syphilis ulcers can bleed easily, allowing HIV to easily enter the bloodstream during sex.
4. Complications during pregnancy and childbirth
If a pregnant woman carries syphilis bacteria, it can be transmitted to the fetus. In addition, congenital syphilis also significantly increases the risk of miscarriage, stillbirth or infant death within a few days of birth.

Syphilis diagnostic test
Besides observing the skin manifestations of people with syphilis, doctors also diagnose the disease through the following test results:
1. Blood test
A blood test will help confirm the presence of antibodies that the body produces to fight infection. Antibodies against the bacteria that cause syphilis remain in the patient's body for many years. Therefore, the test can be used to determine current or past infections.
2. Cerebrospinal fluid
If a person suspects neurological complications related to syphilis, the doctor may also recommend taking a sample of cerebrospinal fluid through a procedure called a lumbar puncture (spinal tap) to confirm the diagnosis.

Treatment of syphilis
Syphilis causes patients to face many health problems. Therefore, when detecting that you are infected with this spirochete, doctors will proceed:
Drug treatment
In the early stages, syphilis is easily cured with medication. Therefore, one of the top choices of doctors is to give patients Penicillin, an antibiotic that can kill the bacteria that cause syphilis and is often effective in most stages. If you are allergic to Penicillin, your doctor may recommend a different antibiotic or Penicillin desensitization.
If diagnosed with primary, secondary or early latent syphilis (less than one year), the recommended treatment is a single injection of Penicillin. For people who have had syphilis for more than a year, the doctor may give an additional dose. Penicillin is also the only recommended treatment for pregnant women with syphilis.
On the first day of treatment, patients may experience a Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction, with symptoms including fever, chills, nausea, aches and pains and headaches. This reaction usually does not last more than a day.
Monitor treatment
After you are treated for syphilis with medication, your doctor will ask the patient to:
Periodic check-ups and blood tests to ensure that the person is responding to the usual dosage of Penicillin. Specific monitoring depends on the stage of syphilis diagnosed.; Avoid having sex with a new partner until treatment is complete and blood tests show the infection is cured.; Notify sexual partners so they can be examined and treated if necessary; Test to see if you are infected with the HIV virus.

Prevention of syphilis
Syphilis can be detected and treated effectively with specific antibiotics to inhibit the growth of the spirochete Treponema pallidum. However, because there is still no vaccine for the disease, prevention is better than cure. You can prevent your risk of getting sick by following these tips:
Do not have promiscuous sex. Be monogamous.; Use condoms to reduce the risk of infection, paying special attention to covering damaged areas.; Avoid using stimulants and alcohol to maintain good judgment and avoid unsafe sexual practices.; Do not share personal items with others to avoid bacteria remaining on surfaces and spreading through open wounds.; If syphilis is discovered before giving birth, the mother needs to notify the doctor for instructions on how to care for herself and prevent infection to the baby.; Follow the regular health check-up schedule every 6 months or as advised by your doctor; Enhance resistance by building a balanced menu, exercising regularly, avoiding stress.; Even though syphilis has been treated, the patient is still at risk of reinfection, so he or she should comply with the treatment course and take preventive measures recommended by a specialist.

Can syphilis be cured?
The disease can be completely cured if detected in the early stages, when the bacteria have not deeply damaged internal organs such as the heart, nerves, etc.
As soon as they discover that they are at risk of syphilis infection, the patient should quickly go to specialized medical facilities for diagnosis and treatment. Don't wait until clear symptoms appear to see a doctor, because the condition may be serious and difficult to cure completely.
For women, before planning pregnancy, it is also necessary to check for bacterial infection. If so, take time to complete treatment before getting pregnant. If the disease is detected during pregnancy, the patient should discuss with an obstetrician for treatment and limit the risk of infection to the baby.
Although syphilis can be cured, patients should not be subjective and not treat it according to the doctor's regimen. Late detection, non-compliance with the regimen, and interruptions can all make bacteria resistant to the drug and make treatment ineffective.

How is syphilis transmitted?
Similar to other sexually transmitted diseases, syphilis also has common transmission routes including:
Through heterosexual sex, homosexual sex, oral sex... In addition, if a sick person and a healthy person have direct contact with a scratched skin surface, the disease can also be transmitted.; Through blood such as when sharing needles, blood transfusions... during vaccination and disease treatment; Through mother to child during pregnancy. Therefore, pregnant women need to have diagnostic tests in all three trimesters to make sure they are not infected or have timely treatment.

How dangerous is syphilis for pregnant women?
Pregnant women have poor resistance, and giving birth makes them need special attention. When pregnant women are infected with syphilis, it not only affects their health and their pregnancy, but also puts the fetus in danger.
Specifically, depending on the stage, syphilis has certain effects on pregnant mothers such as: damage to the skin, mucous membranes, internal organs, muscles, bones... Besides, when the spirochete Treponema pallidum invades the fetus, the fetus Children will be at risk of arteritis and death; stillbirth or premature birth... If born, the baby will have congenital syphilis with complications such as blindness, deaf ears, meningitis...

Does syphilis cause itching?
Many people often think that syphilis chancres can cause itching and that is also one of the signs to identify the disease, but in reality this is not the case. Andrology experts believe that within 10-90 days after being infected with syphilis, the patient will have small, red or brown ulcers, the size of a coin, on the genitals, palms, and hands. soles of the feet... However, these rashes usually do not cause itching and are unclear, so patients can easily ignore them or confuse them with other diseases.

Be monogamous.; Use condoms to reduce the risk of infection, paying special attention to covering damaged areas.; Avoid using stimulants and alcohol to maintain good judgment and avoid unsafe sexual practices.; Do not share personal items with others to avoid bacteria remaining on surfaces and spreading through open wounds.; If syphilis is discovered before giving birth, the mother needs to notify the doctor for instructions on how to care for herself and prevent infection to the baby.; Follow the regular health check-up schedule every 6 months or as advised by your doctor; Enhance resistance by building a balanced menu, exercising regularly, avoiding stress.; Even though syphilis has been treated, the patient is still at risk of reinfection, so he or she should comply with the treatment course and take preventive measures recommended by a specialist.

subsections.subsection_content:
The disease can be completely cured if detected in the early stages, when the bacteria have not deeply damaged internal organs such as the heart, nerves, etc.
As soon as they discover that they are at risk of syphilis infection, the patient should quickly go to specialized medical facilities for diagnosis and treatment. Don't wait until clear symptoms appear to see a doctor, because the condition may be serious and difficult to cure completely.
For women, before planning pregnancy, it is also necessary to check for bacterial infection. If so, take time to complete treatment before getting pregnant. If the disease is detected during pregnancy, the patient should discuss with an obstetrician for treatment and limit the risk of infection to the baby.
Although syphilis can be cured, patients should not be subjective and not treat it according to the doctor's regimen. Late detection, non-compliance with the regimen, and interruptions can all make bacteria resistant to the drug and make treatment ineffective.

subsections.subsection_content:
Similar to other sexually transmitted diseases, syphilis also has common transmission routes including:
Through heterosexual sex, homosexual sex, oral sex... In addition, if a sick person and a healthy person have direct contact with a scratched skin surface, the disease can also be transmitted.; Through blood such as when sharing needles, blood transfusions... during vaccination and disease treatment; Through mother to child during pregnancy. Therefore, pregnant women need to have diagnostic tests in all three trimesters to make sure they are not infected or have timely treatment.

subsections.subsection_name: How dangerous is syphilis for pregnant women?
subsections.subsection_content:
Pregnant women have poor resistance, and giving birth makes them need special attention. When pregnant women are infected with syphilis, it not only affects their health and their pregnancy, but also puts the fetus in danger.
Specifically, depending on the stage, syphilis has certain effects on pregnant mothers such as: damage to the skin, mucous membranes, internal organs, muscles, bones... Besides, when the spirochete Treponema pallidum invades the fetus, the fetus Children will be at risk of arteritis and death; stillbirth or premature birth... If born, the baby will have congenital syphilis with complications such as blindness, deaf ears, meningitis...
